Issues.Title: Tailwind doesn`t check validity of arbitrary values with calc functions
Issues.Body: **What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.1.17 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** Nuxt 4.2.0 **What version of Node.js are you using?** v24.11.1 **What browser are you using?** Firefox **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://play.tailwindcss.com/qUl01FPkEU **Describe your issue** Class like w-[calc(fit-content+50px)] is generating: ``` .w-\[calc\(fit-content\+50px\)\] { width: calc(fit-content + 50px); } ``` but it should not because calc property cannot accept fit-content value
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tailwind doesn`t check validity of arbitrary values with calc functions" (#19486)

Issues.Title: [bug] Upgrade tool stuck at "Migrating templates"
Issues.Body:
Running the migration script is stuck for over half an hour on **"Migrating templates‚Ä¶"**

A lot of files were modified but I am unsure if all the files were scanned or not.

```bash
$ npx @tailwindcss/upgrade
‚âà tailwindcss v4.1.18

‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ Upgrading from Tailwind CSS `v3.4.19` 

‚îÇ Searching for CSS files in the current directory and its subdirectories‚Ä¶ 

‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ Linked `.\frontend\tailwind.config.js` to `.\frontend\src\css\tailwind-base.css` 

‚îÇ Migrating JavaScript configuration files‚Ä¶ 

(node:24000) [MODULE_TYPELESS_PACKAGE_JSON] Warning: Module type of file:///C:/projects/definity/frontend/tailwind.config.js is not specified and it doesn't parse as CommonJS.
Reparsing as ES module because module syntax was detected. This incurs a performance overhead.
To eliminate this warning, add "type": "module" to C:\projects\definity-app\frontend\package.json.
(Use `node --trace-warnings ...` to show where the warning was created)
‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ The configuration file at `.\frontend\tailwind.config.js` could not be automatically migrated to the new 
‚îÇ   CSS configuration format, so your CSS has been updated to load your existing configuration file. 

‚îÇ Migrating stylesheets‚Ä¶

‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ Migrated stylesheet: `.\frontend\src\css\tailwind-base.css` 

‚îÇ Updating dependencies‚Ä¶ 

‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ Updated package: `tailwindcss` 

‚îÇ ‚Ü≥ Updated package: `prettier-plugin-tailwindcss`

‚îÇ Migrating templates‚Ä¶

```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[bug] Upgrade tool stuck at "Migrating templates"" (#19485)

Issues.Title: Can I add 40 lines of `@source`? It decreased my CSS output bytes
Issues.Body:
1. Because of https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/issues/19476, I was compelled to add each symlink manually, a total of 40.
2. Not only did the output CSS size not increase, it decreased instead, seemingly to imply that all 40 lines were ignored
3. It's quite frustrating that Tailwind does not generate logs or errors.
    - which folders and files did it scan?
    - are there any files it could not scan?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Can I add 40 lines of `@source`? It decreased my CSS output bytes" (#19482)

Issues.Title: Class extraction with Rails' strict locals
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.1.18 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** tailwindcss-rails **What browser are you using?** N/A **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://github.com/eelcoj/explicit-locals **Describe your issue** Rails has a feature (since 7.2?) called [explicit locals](https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/45727). Syntax is: `<%# locals: (css: "text-amber-600") %>` In above repo this code: ```erb <%# locals: (css: "text-amber-600") %> <% more_css = "text-sky-500" %>

In a partial

In a partial using explicit local variables

In a partial using explicit local variables

``` Renders as: ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9ae13079-0056-4bf2-813f-7bbb45f9eff6) You can see the before last, is not getting the `text-amber-600`. My guess is Tailwind assumes it is a comment, thus skips the parsing of the line? There is point to be made that this is expected: ‚Äústrict locals are only meant to pass objects‚Äù. But I often use it to pass CSS and then use it to set defaults.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Class extraction with Rails' strict locals" (#19481)

Issues.Title: Tailwind does not scan symlinks
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite 6.4.1

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v12.22.9

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

Windows

**Reproduction URL**

A Tailwind Play link or public GitHub repo that includes a minimal reproduction of the bug. **Please do not link to your actual project**, what we need instead is a _minimal_ reproduction in a fresh project without any unnecessary code. This means it doesn't matter if your real project is private/confidential, since we want a link to a separate, isolated reproduction anyways.

A reproduction is **required** when filing an issue ‚Äî any issue opened without a reproduction will be closed and you'll be asked to create a new issue that includes a reproduction. We're a small team and we can't keep up with the volume of issues we receive if we need to reproduce each issue from scratch ourselves.

**Describe your issue**

1. I have `@source "../../vendor/mine";` in my Laravel's `resource/css/app.css`
2. All the subfolders in `mine` are symlinks, e.g. `../../vendor/mine/symlink1/`, `../../vendor/mine/package2/`
3. Tailwind scanning does not traverse into these symlinks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Tailwind does not scan symlinks" (#19476)

Issues.Title: bun-plugin-tailwind: peerDependency on "bun" causes broken npm bun package to shadow global Bun installation, breaking all scripts
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Bun 1.3.5 with bun-plugin-tailwind 0.1.2

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

N/A (using Bun runtime)

**What browser are you using?**

N/A

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

1. Create a new project: `bun init`
2. Add to package.json:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "bun-plugin-tailwind": "^0.1.2"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "bun --hot src/index.ts"
  }
}
```
3. Run `bun install && bun run dev`

**Describe your issue**

`bun-plugin-tailwind` declares `bun` as a peer dependency in its package.json:

```json
"peerDependencies": {
  "bun": ">=1.0.0"
}
```

This causes Bun to install the `bun` npm package, which creates `node_modules/.bin/bun` and `node_modules/.bin/bunx` symlinks. However, these binaries are 0-byte placeholder files that fail to execute.

When running `bun run <script>`, Bun prepends `node_modules/.bin` to PATH, so it finds the broken npm-installed `bun` binary instead of the global Bun installation. This causes all scripts to silently fail with exit code 1.

**Expected behavior:** Scripts defined in package.json should work with `bun run dev`.

**Workaround:** Add override to package.json to prevent the `bun` npm package from being installed:

```json
"overrides": {
  "bun": "link:."
}
```

**Suggested fix:** Remove `bun` from peerDependencies. Since this plugin only works within the Bun runtime, requiring `bun` as a peer dependency is unnecessary ‚Äî Bun is always present when using this package.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bun-plugin-tailwind: peerDependency on "bun" causes broken npm bun package to shadow global Bun installation, breaking all scripts" (#19471)

Issues.Title: Clarify the `replaceAlpha` function comment
Issues.Body:
## Summary

Updated the comment of the `replaceAlpha` function to clarify the function's purpose.

## Test plan

n/a
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Clarify the `replaceAlpha` function comment" (#19457)

Issues.Title: feat: only polyfill internal, intentional usages of `color-mix`
Issues.Body:
Previous discussion: #19445 

> [!NOTE] 
> This is a proof of concept PR. I don't expect it to be merged, but thought it would be easier to reason about the sense and nonsense of my idea with an actual implementation at hand

## Summary

Prefix internal usage of `color-mix` for adding alpha to colors with `tw-`, so that optimzations (replacing the rule with the first color value, adding a polyfill) isn't applied to user-land CSS.

## Alternatives considered

Use a custom comment instead, e.g. `/* tw:polyfill-color-mix */ color-mix()`. Went for the "hacky" approach with the non-native `tw-color-mix()` function for now, as this approach is much more straight-forward in the CSS parsing and AST functions.

## Test plan & other Notes

- Added a (first-failing) test "does not apply optimizations to native color-mix()"
- Updated all tests that were failing
- Apply the alpha in the `:placeholder` rule in preflight manually, to keep the css valid case that file would be loaded without directly from somewhere

## Breaking Change

What speaks against this: It would be a breaking change. People might be relying on tailwindcss polyfilling their custom `color-mix` CSS.

Feel free to close this. But at least now we have something to look at in the future, should it come up somewhere else again üôÇ
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat: only polyfill internal, intentional usages of `color-mix`" (#19456)

Issues.Title: Source classes are not detected correctly when specified as `data-loading="addClass(opacity-50)"`
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.1.18 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** https://github.com/SymfonyCasts/tailwind-bundle **What version of Node.js are you using?** N/A **What browser are you using?** Chrome **What operating system are you using?** Windows **Reproduction URL** N/A **Describe your issue** In [Symfony live components](https://symfony.com/bundles/ux-live-component/current/index.html), usually one defines the `data-loading` attribute with the `addClass` directive, like this: ```html
``` The source analysis mechanism for extracting CSS classes fails in this case, and the `opacity-50` class is not added to the output.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Source classes are not detected correctly when specified as `data-loading="addClass(opacity-50)"`" (#19458)

Issues.Title: `color-mix()` should not be transpiled with custom properties
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.1.18

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite, reproducible in playground

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

n/a

**What browser are you using?**

n/a

**What operating system are you using?**

n/a

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/vfK8S6Q1Ry?file=css (look at the class `.via-ease-in-sine` in the "Generated CSS" panel)

**Describe your issue**

I've got a custom directive using `color-mix` with two custom properties, as [described here](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/19441).

## What I expected

I'd expect no transpilation to happen if I use custom properties in color-mix:

```css
.via-ease-in-sine {
  --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0%) 0%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0.8%) 8.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 2.9%) 15.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 6.2%) 22.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 10.1%) 29%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 14.8%) 35.3%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 20.1%) 41.2%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 26.2%) 47.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 32.8%) 52.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 40%) 58.8%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 47.8%) 64.7%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 56.6%) 71%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 66.3%) 77.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 77.1%) 84.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 88.7%) 91.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 100%) 100%;
}

```

## What actually happened

my color-mix directives are being transpiled, and in a way that makes no sense. Transpiled css code:

```css
.via-ease-in-sine {
    --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 0%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 8.1%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 15.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 22.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 29%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 35.3%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 41.2%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 47.1%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 52.9%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 58.8%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 64.7%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 71%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 77.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 84.5%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 91.9%,
    var(--tw-gradient-from) 100%;
    @supports (color: color-mix(in lab, red, red)) {
      --tw-gradient-via-stops: var(--tw-gradient-position),
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0%) 0%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 0.8%) 8.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 2.9%) 15.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 6.2%) 22.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 10.1%) 29%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 14.8%) 35.3%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 20.1%) 41.2%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 26.2%) 47.1%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 32.8%) 52.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 40%) 58.8%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 47.8%) 64.7%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 56.6%) 71%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 66.3%) 77.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 77.1%) 84.5%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 88.7%) 91.9%,
    color-mix(in oklab, var(--tw-gradient-from), var(--tw-gradient-to) 100%) 100%;
    }
  }
```

At first I thought this was a lightning css issue and posted [an issue on their repo](https://github.com/parcel-bundler/lightningcss/issues/1111). But then I tried it in the [lightningcss playground](https://lightningcss.dev/playground/#%7B%22minify%22%3Afalse%2C%22customMedia%22%3Afalse%2C%22cssModules%22%3Afalse%2C%22analyzeDependencies%22%3Afalse%2C%22targets%22%3A%7B%22chrome%22%3A6225920%7D%2C%22include%22%3A1113088%2C%22exclude%22%3A0%2C%22source%22%3A%22%2F*%5Cn%20*%20Add%20easing%20to%20tailwind%20linear%20gradient%20stops%5Cn%20*%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Fplay.tailwindcss.com%2FyMgz1p5Fx5%3Ffile%3Dcss%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Flarsenwork.com%2Feasing-gradients%2F%5Cn%20*%20%40see%20https%3A%2F%2Fgist.github.com%2Fmatthewbeta%2F0ef11bd907b435f101e09cc6216ad66b%5Cn%20*%2F%5Cn.via-ease-in-sine%20%7B%5Cn%20%20--tw-gradient-via-stops%3A%20var(--tw-gradient-position)%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%200%25)%200%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%200.8%25)%208.1%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%202.9%25)%2015.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%206.2%25)%2022.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2010.1%25)%2029%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2014.8%25)%2035.3%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2020.1%25)%2041.2%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2026.2%25)%2047.1%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2032.8%25)%2052.9%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2040%25)%2058.8%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2047.8%25)%2064.7%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2056.6%25)%2071%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2066.3%25)%2077.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2077.1%25)%2084.5%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%2088.7%25)%2091.9%25%2C%5Cn%20%20%20%20color-mix(in%20oklab%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-from)%2C%20var(--tw-gradient-to)%20100%25)%20100%25%3B%5Cn%7D%22%2C%22visitorEnabled%22%3Afalse%2C%22visitor%22%3A%22%7B%5Cn%20%20Color(color)%20%7B%5Cn%20%20%20%20if%20(color.type%20%3D%3D%3D%20'rgb')%20%7B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20color.g%20%3D%200%3B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20return%20color%3B%5Cn%20%20%20%20%7D%5Cn%20%20%7D%5Cn%7D%22%2C%22unusedSymbols%22%3A%5B%5D%2C%22version%22%3A%22local%22%7D) and couldn't reproduce it there. 

So this might be something that happens within tailwindcss, before the code is being sent to lightningcss? I don't know.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`color-mix()` should not be transpiled with custom properties" (#19445)

Issues.Title: Ring offset CSS variable does not work
Issues.Body: **What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.1.17 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** @rslib/core v0.18.0 (wrapping @rsbuild/core v1.6.7), using @tailwindcss/postcss v4.1.17 **What version of Node.js are you using?** v25.2.1 **What browser are you using?** N/A (Issue is with CSS generation/application) **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://play.tailwindcss.com/NhfXz9PhUc **Describe your issue** I am attempting to use a CSS variable for the `ring-offset` utility using the arbitrary value syntax in Tailwind CSS v4, but it does not appear to apply the style. I have a variable defined in my CSS within a `@theme static` block: ```css @theme static { --ring-offset-slider: var(--spacing-050); } ``` I am trying to use this variable in a class string: ```tsx // Attempt 1 (Tailwind v4 variable syntax) className="focus-visible:ring-offset-(--ring-offset-slider)" // Attempt 2 (Arbitrary value syntax) className="focus-visible:ring-offset-[var(--ring-offset-slider)]" ``` Neither of these result in the expected `ring-offset-width` being applied. However, using a hardcoded value works correctly: ```tsx // Works className="focus-visible:ring-offset-2" ``` I expected `focus-visible:ring-offset-(--ring-offset-slider)` to generate the equivalent of `ring-offset-width: var(--ring-offset-slider)` (or the corresponding implementation in v4), but it seems to be ignored or invalid.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Ring offset CSS variable does not work" (#19452)

Issues.Title: Dynamic responsive variants (max-*/min-*) do not honor custom breakpoints defined in @theme static, while unprefixed variants do
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.x (verified on at least 4.0.6) **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** Nuxt UI (Nuxt 3+), Tailwind CLI, and also tested with Vite 6.1.0 **What version of Node.js are you using?** v20.x **What browser are you using?** Any (problem is about generated CSS) **What operating system are you using?** Tested on macOS and Linux (occurs in all environments) **Reproduction URL** [Reproduction repository](https://github.com/ivan-angjelkoski/tailwindcss-breakpoint-static-bug-demo) **Describe your issue** When defining custom breakpoints using `@theme static` in CSS (for example: ```css @theme static { --breakpoint-sm: 640px; --breakpoint-md: 768px; } ``` ) ...the responsive classes like `sm:` use my custom breakpoints as expected. However, functional responsive variants like `max-sm:` and `min-md:` fall back to Tailwind's built-in defaults instead of using my custom values. **Example:** ```css @theme static { --breakpoint-sm: 640px; --breakpoint-md: 768px; } ``` In markup: ```
Test
``` **Generates:** - `sm:p-2` ‚Üí `@media (min-width: 640px)` (correct) - `max-sm:p-3` ‚Üí `@media (max-width: 639px)` (fallbacks to Tailwind default 639px, not the static value) - `min-md:p-4` ‚Üí `@media (min-width: 768px)` (fallbacks to Tailwind default 768px, not the static value) Unprefixed breakpoints (`sm:`, `md:`, etc.) work as expected, but dynamic variants `max-*` and `min-*` ignore the custom definitions when using `@theme static`. If you use `@theme` or `@theme default`, this problem disappears, but using `static` is required for my scenario (for Nuxt UI or integration constraints). **Why this matters** - Projects using Tailwind CSS v4+ with custom breakpoint management in CSS need all responsive variants to respect user-defined breakpoints regardless of theme block type. - Duplicating breakpoints between `@theme static` and non-static theme blocks is not a sustainable workaround. **Steps to reproduce** 1. Use `@theme static` to define custom breakpoints (e.g., `--breakpoint-sm: 640px;`) 2. Add classes such as `sm:p-2`, `max-sm:p-3`, and `min-md:p-4` in your markup 3. Build and inspect the generated CSS and see that max/min prefixed variants use default values **Expected:** All responsive variants use my custom breakpoints, regardless of theme block method. **Actual:** Only unprefixed variants do; `max-*` and `min-*` do not support custom statically-defined breakpoints. See also: https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/23347 /cc @ivan-angjelkoski
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dynamic responsive variants (max-*/min-*) do not honor custom breakpoints defined in @theme static, while unprefixed variants do" (#19446)
